title: Does your partner always seem hot and cold for no obvious reason?
caption: false

channel_info.title: Robbie Kramer
channel_info.description:
I'm Robbie Kramer 🎙Host of The Inner Confidence Podcast & Founder of Inner Confidence, Inc.

I lived an exhilarating single life filled with adventures and lessons, and ultimately achieved what I had always aspired to – finding an amazing, feminine, and loving wife. 

I believe my experiences provide a rare balance of wild freedom and committed love, equipping me with the insights to help you navigate the complexities of dating and relationships in today's world. Let me guide you to embrace your desires, improve your social prowess, and ultimately attract the partner who aligns with your highest aspirations.

You won’t find any fluffy, new-age, or cringy stuff here, just tested, proven and actionable advice that yields results.

Apply to join our exclusive Inner Confidence Community of ambitious men who are actively working together to achieve their goals faster   ► https://innerconfidence.com/community

You can email me at robbie@innerconfidence.com with any questions or comments.

transcription: {"text": "She would get high all the time and just mentally check out. See, for y'all, it seems like it's hot and cold, hot and cold from kind of beginning to end. For me, it's like specifically for a girl to guy situation where the guy is avoidant, or just my situation. But for me, it was like very, very hot. And then like towards the half mark and then started getting more and more cold. Yeah, I remember when this happened. He would sort of sabotage it and then he would lose it and then he would rush it back and then he would sabotage again. It was more of a hot and cold towards the end. Yeah, but it was like, like hot, hot, hot. And then it's like, okay, shit, there's a lot of women can see it. I'm gonna sabotage this and then wait, but no one else is there to catch me. Oh, let me get her back and like do something really awesome and then, okay, back and forth. Does that resonate, Robby? Yeah, well, they want the comfort and the security of like having someone, right? It's like, that's why these people that we're describing, they're always in a relationship, but like it's kind of just for the security of being in a relationship when they're not actually doing the things that require the relationship to function.
